Award.AwardTitle: SCC-Planning: Defining Research and Education Challenges in IoT for Neighborhoods with Significant Numbers of Small-to-Mid-Sized Manufacturers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Smart and connected systems are changing communities, work, and the home profoundly.  Automation over the past few decades has radically reshaped manufacturing, employment in manufacturing industries, and their local communities. The Internet of Things (IoT) will likely accelerate change, opening new opportunities and presenting new challenges. This grant brings together academic researchers in science, engineering, and business management at two universities, educators, community members and city leaders, and small-to-mid-sized manufacturers (SMM), all within a neighborhood of Cleveland, Ohio, to plan for research, education, and workforce development in their community.

This project develops action plans for research, education, and policy recommendations to benefit SMMs and the local community.  The plans reflect an understanding of the investment in time and resources required to leverage IoT in order for the SMMs to transform themselves into "smart" manufacturers with increased productivity and energy efficiency to better capitalize on new markets.  Within the local community, the plans reflect an understanding of the potential role of IoT in workforce education, recruitment, and retention. IoT has the potential to improve the quality of life of a community.  This project brings these different perspectives together, creating a new language for engagement among stakeholders and creating new opportunities in a community for public-private investment in IoT-enabled technologies and applications. This project in a neighborhood of Ohio may serve as a model for small towns and communities to work and plan with their local universities and manufacturers to achieve the societal benefits from leveraging IoT technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past few decades, smart and connected systems and IoT (Internet of Things) have had significant impact on our daily lives and reshaped the manufacturing landscape, affecting not only the way products are made, but also the workforce and the communities where the manufacturing is located. These changes provide new opportunities while also presenting new challenges.

This NSF planning grant brings together academic researchers in engineering, science, and business management at two universities, high school educators, community members, city leaders, and small-to-mid-sized manufacturers (SMMs), all within a neighborhood of Cleveland, Ohio, to plan activities towards a systematic investigation of the advantages, limitations, and potential impact of IoT technologies on Small and Mid-sized Manufacturers (SMMs) and the communities in which the companies are located. These activities have been conducted through surveys of the needs from SMMs and the community, as well as their interests in IoT, to establish a platform for future research, education, and workforce development that contribute to reviving the SMMs and their target communities.

The intellectual merit, and the major outcome of this project, is a deeper understanding of the investment in time and resources required to leverage IoT in order for the SMMs to: 1) transform themselves into ?smart? manufacturers with increased productivity and energy efficiency to better capitalize on new markets, 2) use IoT within the target community to enhance workforce education, recruitment, and retention, and 3) make SMMs more responsive to OEMs and larger supply chains through improved maintenance strategies, spare part policies, and neighborhood recommendations in using IoT principles to optimize solutions to community problems. Within the local community, the understanding promotes the potential role of IoT in workforce education, recruitment, and retention, towards improvement of the quality of life of the community.  Through this planning grant, a close working relationship was developed between Case Western Reserve University and various partners, e.g., Cleveland State University (academic partner), WIRE-Net (industry partner), Bellaire-Puritas Development Corporation (community partner), and principals and teachers at John Marshall High School. In addition, companies were identified that are interested in serving as a test bed for implementing and evaluating the hardware and software capabilities that the CWRU team will develop for IoT-enabled machine operation monitoring, fault diagnosis, and remaining useful life prediction, to be described in detail in a regular proposal to NSF?s Smart and Connected Community program.   

The broader impact of this planning grant is that it has engaged a wide range of constituents of the community in Cleveland, Ohio, where the project was conducted - manufacturers, business owners, researchers, policy makers, teachers, students, and parents.  This has allowed for a collective discussion on what it means to be a smart community and how IoT can enable this vision to be realized. Such a conversation will result in a new vocabulary of engagement, a new way of interacting, a new set of relationships that aim to develop technology and research in a way that has broad benefits for the public, and for individual citizens.  This planning grant has brought science and engineering to life in an economically and racially diverse community, and can serve as a model for small towns and neighborhoods to work with their local universities and manufacturers to achieve great societal benefits by leveraging IoT technologies.
